t: A*p pronouncement concerning Damascus: Look,*pn Damascus is no longer a city. It*ln has become a ruined heap.
The*ln cities of Aroer are abandoned; they*ln will be places for flocks. They*ln will lie down without fear.
The*pn fortress disappears from Ephraim, and*ln a kingdom from Damascus. The*ln remnant of Aram will be like*ln the splendor of the Israelites. This*lg is the declaration of the Lord*s of Armies.
On*pn that day the*ln splendor of Jacob will fade, and*ln his healthy body will become emaciated.
It*ln will be as if a reaper had gathered standing grain — his*ln arm harvesting the heads of grain — and*ln as if one had gleaned heads of grain in*ln Rephaim Valley.

Only*pn gleanings will be left in Israel, as*ln if an olive tree had been beaten — two*ln or three olives at the very top of the tree, four*ln or five on its fruitful branches. This*lg is the declaration of the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
On*p that day people will look to their Maker and will turn their eyes to the Holy One of Israel.
They will not look to the altars they made with their hands or to the Asherahs and shrines they made with their fingers.
On*pn that day their strong cities will be like*ln the abandoned woods and mountaintops that*ln were abandoned because of the Israelites; there*ln will be desolation.

For*pn you have forgotten the God of your salvation, and*ln you have failed to remember the*ln rock of your strength; therefore*ln you will plant beautiful plants and*ln set out cuttings from exotic vines.
On*ln the day that you plant, you*ln will help them to grow, and*ln in the morning you*ln will help your seed to sprout, but*ln the harvest will vanish on*ln the day of disease and incurable pain.
Ah!*pn The roar of many peoples — they*ln roar like the roaring of the seas. The*ln raging of the nations — they*ln rage like the rumble of rushing water.
The*ln nations rage like the rumble of a huge torrent. He*ln rebukes them, and they flee far away, driven*ln before the wind like chaff on the hills and*ln like tumbleweeds before a gale.
In*ln the evening - sudden terror! Before*ln morning - it is gone! This*ln is the fate of those who plunder us and*ln the lot of those who ravage us.
